oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Ecological niche is a key concept that links species distributions. Ecological niche shifts are expected to affect the potential invasive risk of alien species. <jats:italic>Rapistrum rugosum</jats:italic> is an invasive agricultural weed in many countries. Wild populations of <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> have been recorded in China, representing a great threat to the regional crops. Based on distribution records from different regions and relevant environmental variables, the present study predicted the potential distribution and estimated the invasive risk of <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> in China. Ecological niche shifts strongly affected the potential invasive risk of <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> in China. The two most important variables were annual temperature range (Bio7) and mean temperature of the coldest quarter (Bio11). The total suitable habitat for the species covered an area of 287.53 × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>km<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> and was mainly distributed in Southwest, Southeast, and Central China. Australia, Canada, Brazil, the United States, and Argentina accounted for over 90% of the inspection records of <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> from Chinese entry ports during 2015–2018. The intercepted <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> was frequently mixed in <jats:italic>Glycine max</jats:italic> (L.) Merr., <jats:italic>Hordeum vulgare</jats:italic> L., linseed, <jats:italic>Triticum aestivum</jats:italic> L., and <jats:italic>Sorghum bicolor</jats:italic> (L.) Moench. Moreover, 80% interceptions were recorded from Tianjin, Guangdong, Nanjing, and Chengdu customs. Climatic conditions do not limit the establishment capability of <jats:italic>R. rugosum</jats:italic> in China. Our results provide a theoretical reference for the development of monitoring and control measures for this invasive weed.</jats:p>
